item.title: Las Vegas Reopens; Covid-19 Ravages Latin America
item.description: Some of Las Vegas’s biggest resorts and convention centers are to resume business as Nevada seeks to recover from the biggest hit to the workforce of any U.S. state. Brazil and Mexico, Latin America’s biggest countries, reported record death tolls—more than 2,500 dead between them.

item.title: Iran Frees U.S. Navy Veteran After Two Years in Detention
item.description: Iran released U.S. Navy veteran Michael White after nearly two years in custody as part of a prisoner deal negotiated with Iran.

item.title: Putin Declares Emergency Over Massive Arctic Fuel Spill
item.description: Investigators have launched a criminal probe into a spill at a power plant after the Russian leader upbraided a senior official for his handling of the incident.

item.title: Thousands Defy Beijing With Hong Kong Vigil for Tiananmen Victims
item.description: Crowds congregated across Hong Kong on Thursday evening to light candles and remember victims of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre, defying a police ban to gather hours after the city’s legislature passed a law making disrespect of China’s national anthem a crime.

item.title: China to Allow Foreign Airlines to Restore Some Flights, After U.S. Pressure
item.description: China made a rare concession in the face of U.S. pressure by agreeing to allow U.S. and other foreign airlines to restore some China routes, less than 24 hours after the Trump administration had threatened to bar Chinese airlines from the U.S.

item.title: Kim Jong Un's Sister Threatens South Korea Over Leaflets
item.description: The sister of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un admonished South Korea and threatened to pull out of an inter-Korean accord, the latest sign of her growing profile inside the cloistered regime.
